description: Borrowed into Middle English from Old French trenche.

entries.meaning: A long, narrow ditch or hole dug in the ground.
(military) A narrow excavation as used in warfare, as a cover for besieging or emplaced forces.
(archaeology) A pit, usually rectangular with smooth walls and floor, excavated during an archaeological investigation.

examples: I was the first person in my high school to wear a trench and fedora constantly, and Ben was one of the first to wear a black trench.

verbs.description: trench (third-person singular simple present trenches, present participle trenching, simple past and past participle trenched)

entries.meaning: (usually followed by upon) To invade, especially with regard to the rights or the exclusive authority of another; to encroach.
examples: Shee is the Judge, Thou Executioner, Or if thou needs would'st trench upon her power, Thou mightst have yet enjoy'd thy crueltie, With some more thrift, and more varietie.

entries.meaning: (military, infantry) To excavate an elongated pit for protection of soldiers and or equipment, usually perpendicular to the line of sight toward the enemy.
examples: Advanc'd upon the field there stood a moundOf earth congested, wall'd , and trench'd around

entries.meaning: (archaeology) To excavate an elongated and often narrow pit.
To have direction; to aim or tend.
To cut; to form or shape by cutting; to make by incision, hewing, etc.
To cut furrows or ditches in.
examples: to trench land for the purpose of draining it

entries.meaning: To dig or cultivate very deeply, usually by digging parallel contiguous trenches in succession, filling each from the next.
examples: to trench a garden for certain crops
